samples.reference: systematic simulations are carried out based on the model of fluidized beds proposed by the present authors [ k.ichiki and h.hayakawa , phys . rev . e * 52 * , 658 ( 1995 ) ] . from our simulation , we confirm that fluidization is a continuous transition . we also confirm the existence of two types of fluidized phases , the channeling phase and the bubbling phase . we find the close relations between the averaged behaviors in fluidized beds and quasi equilibrium states in dense liquids . in fluidized beds , ( i ) the flow rate plays the role of the effective temperature , and ( ii ) the existence of a kind of the fluctuation - dissipation relation is suggested .
samples.generated: we have performed a systematic simulation of fluidized beds , where energy injection is controlled by the flow of fluid at the bottom . we have observed the transition of fluidization from the fixed phase to the fluidized phase and the existence of two fluidized phases .<n> we have also discussed statistical quantities , which are analogous to equilibrium correspondences . we perform molecular dynamics simulations of a fluidized bed in two dimensions .<n> we find that the flow - rate dependence of the viscosity @xmath0 is consistent with the einstein relation and the fluctuation - dissipation relation in the bubbling phase . in the channeling phase ,<n> the viscosity decreases with the flow rate , while the viscosity increases with the channel - bubble transition rate . <n> when a fluid is in a highly nonequilibrium state , the relative motion of particles or the kinetic energy is generated by bubbles which have the difference of the local volume fraction in the system . because the bubbles are always accompanied by the convective motion of the particles , they become obscure as the velocity of the fluid increases . as a result<n> , we see surprising correspondences in statistical quantities between fluidized beds and quasi equilibrium systems . from the previous paper @xcite or in fig . [ fig : eng - time - fb - st ] , here we discuss the behavior of particles in a fluidization bed in the presence of a heat bath . if the temperature is lower than the critical temperature of the system such as that in a liquid , there is no fluidization . on the other hand , we have carried out numerical simulations of a model of fluidized beds . we have found two fluidized phases , _ the channeling phase _ and , the _ bubbling phase_, where the former changes to the latter as the flow rate @xmath0 of the fluid increases .<n> we have defined the effective viscosity as the ratio of the energy to generate the free volume to the viscosity . in terms of the effective temperature ,<n> we find that the viscosity can be an index of the non - gaussian property in velocity distribution of particles , which is consistent with the hole theory in simple liquids . <n> the phase transition between the fluidized phase and the bubbling phase was observed in experiments@xcite , and it was interpreted as a discontinuous phase transition . on the other hand , in our simulation , we can not find the homogeneous phase , since the bubbling behavior is not observed in the experiments . the phase diagram of the model is presented in fig . [ fig - fig - st - model - simulation ] , where we show the flow - rate dependence of the critical value of the stokes number and the critical point of the transition area . since the phase transitions are observed we present a model for the dynamics of fluidized beds .<n> the model is based on the concept of the effective stokes number @xmath0 , which is the ratio of the hydrodynamic force to the drag force acting on the particles . in the fluidized bed ,<n> the frictional drag is proportional to the friction coefficient of the fluid , while the drag due to the convective motion of the bed is proportional with the fluid velocity . for small friction coefficient<n> , we get the well - known frictional - drag relation , whereas for large friction coefficient we get a non - linear relation between the drag coefficient and the fluid density . <n> pacs numbers : 87.10.+e , 05.70.ln , 47.20.ky 2 recently , there has been a growing interest in the non - equilibrium dynamics of fluids , especially in the case of beds @xcite . from the theoretical point of view , the most interesting situation is when the particles are in contact with each other , because this is the case in most of the real systems , such as beds , planes , etc .@xcite in such a situation , it is important to

samples.source_preview:
romanowsky et al . ( 2003 ) have recently presented dynamical studies of three elliptical galaxies based on the measurement of radial velocities of a large number of planetary nebulae in each of these galaxies . 
 this method is rather more reliable , and is extended to considerably larger radii , than the standard method of interpreting the line - of - sight - integrated line profiles ( see e.g. , gerhard et al . 
 2001 , and baes and dejonghe 2002 ) .

samples.reference: the recent findings of romanowsky et al . , of an `` unexpectedly '' small mass discrepancy within 5 effective radii in several elliptical galaxies , are not surprising in the context of mond . as we show here , they are , in fact , in full concordance with its predictions . one is dealing with high - surface - density galaxies with mean accelerations rather larger than the acceleration constant of mond . these findings continue , and are now the extreme examples of , the trend predicted by mond : the mass discrepancy sets in at larger and larger scaled radii in galaxies with larger and larger mean surface densities ; or , equivalently , mean accelerations .
samples.generated: we point out that the results of romanowsky et al . <n> ( 2003 ) , based on the study of planetary nebulae kinematics in three elliptical galaxies , go beyond existing support for mond , and probe , as they do , the highest acceleration end in the galaxy sequence , higher than what has been probed with rotation curves of spiral galaxies . we show that mond predicts the high acceleration end of the galaxy distribution to be @xmath0 , in unit of radius , for galaxies with measured extended rotation curves .<n> this is consistent with mond s prediction , and confirms it for the first three galaxies studied here , as well as m87 and m49 . <n> we have previously shown that , from the observed light distribution , it is possible to define a  maximum disk '' , whereby the rotation curve in the inner regions is explained by the visible disk with a reasonable dark matter ( dm ) mass fraction @xcite . here<n> , we study the extent to which the rotation curves of the galaxies under study , deduced from the light distribution assuming a constant dm mass fraction , agree well with the mond predictions , assuming very reasonable orbit populations . in the case of ngc 3379 ,<n> for example , which has the best studied rotation curve among the galaxies studied , the inferred mass discrepancy between the observed rotation curve and the deduced one is as large as 40 percent , at the outermost measured point , with a typical uncertainty in the deduced value of about 20 percent . for ng we report on the formation of a vortex - field dependence of the vortex pair formation temperature is in good agreement with the results of time - dependent density - functional theory ( tddft ) . <n> the discovery of superconductivity in the iron - based superconductors ( scs ) @xcite has triggered the theoretical and experimental study of the properties of high-@xmath1 cuprates . in particular , it has been shown that the superconducting transition temperature depends on the ratio of the effective mass of the superconducting order parameter to the density of states at the fermi level , a quantity which is determined by the bcs theory . on the other hand ,<n> it has also been demonstrated that the zero - samples.source_preview:
the bcs theory is considered as a conventional theory of superconductivity at a microscopic level , where bosonic excitations like phonons or spin fluctuations play the role of mediators in the formation of cooper pairs and hence superconductivity occurs in a metallic state . in recent years many varieties of superconductors have been discovered which are unconventional . 
 some examples are    1 . 
 cuprates , where anisotropic d - wave gaps occur with nodes ( vanishing gap ) at some symmetry p
samples.reference: the recently discovered multiband superconductors have created a new class of novel superconductors . in these materials multiple superconducting gaps arise due to the formation of cooper pairs on different sheets of the fermi surfaces . an important feature of these superconductors is the interband couplings , which not only change the individual gap properties , but also create new collective modes . here we investigate the effect of the interband couplings in the ginzburg - landau theory . we produce a general @xmath0 expansion ( @xmath1 ) and show that this expansion has unexpected behaviour for @xmath2 . this point emphasises the weaker validity of the gl theory for lower temperatures and gives credence to the existence of hidden criticality near the critical temperature of the uncoupled subdominant band .

our present knowledge about elementary particles and their interactions upto the energy scale of several hundred gev s is encapsulated in the theory called the standard model(sm ) . 
 the sm , a renormalizable gauge theory of strong and electroweak interactions based on the guage group @xmath3 , gives a successful explanation for most of the phenomena governing fundamental processes , and is in excellent agreement with the experimental data to date . however , there are a number of unanswered qu

samples.source_preview:
clarification of the chiral phase transition and the confinement / deconfinement transition are the longstanding central issues in qcd . 
 there have been numerous efforts to understand the phase structure of qcd at zero and finite temperature or density regions  @xcite . 
 chiral phase transition is detected by monitoring the order parameter , chiral condensate @xmath2 , whereas a polyakov loop is widely used in order to know whether a system is in the confinement phase or not .

vanishing quark chemical potentials ,<n> we show that the phase angle of the determinant grows as we increase the chemical potential and finally saturates at some value , which corresponds to the deconfinement phase transition . <n> it has been a long - standing problem whether or not the quark - antiquark system in a finite volume has a confining vacuum . in ref . @xcite<n> , it was found that the system does not have a confining phase , even though the quarks in the full configuration do have an infinite number of net charges . on the other hand , in the quenched case , there is no evidence for confining behavior , since the system has a finite number of quarks . to clarify the situation , we propose a new prescription , where we evaluate a polyakov - samples.source_preview:
given the increasing age of many industrial systems and the dynamic industrial manufacturing market , intelligent and low - cost industrial automation systems are required to improve the productivity and efficiency of such systems [ 1 ] . 
 the collaborative nature of industrial wireless sensor networks ( iwsns ) brings several advantages over traditional wired industrial monitoring and control systems , including self - organization , rapid deployment , flexibility , and inherent intelligent -
samples.reference: with the development of wireless communication , industrial wireless sensor networks ( iwsns ) plays an important role in monitoring and control systems . in this paper , we extend the application of iwsns into high frequency surface - wave radar ( hfswr ) system . the traditional antenna is replaced by mobile iwsns . in combination of the application precondition of super - directivity in hf band and circular topology of iwsns , a super - directivity synthesis method is presented for designing super - directivity array . in this method , the dominance of external noise is ensured by constraining the ratio of external to internal noise ( rein ) of the array , and the desired side lobe level is achieved by implementing linear constraint . by using this method , the highest directivity will be achieved in certain conditions . using the designed super directive circular array as sub - arrays , the compact receive antenna array is constructed , the purpose of miniaturization is achieved . simulation verifies that the proposed method is correct and effective , the validity of the proposed method has been proved .
samples.generated: in this paper , super directive circular array is designed and compared by using industrial wireless sensor networks ( iwsns ) .<n> the highest directivity with certain constrains is achieved , and the size of the received antenna array is reduced . computer simulation verifies the correctness and affectivity of the proposed method . for high frequency surface - wave radar ( hfswr )<n> , the elements , which can monitor enemy aircrafts and missiles , are usually deployed near the coastline . in order to monitor enemy air targets , deployment regions of mwsns are vitally important to protect the military base . and<n> because the array size is very large , it is required that the array has super directivity . in this paper , we present a super - directivity synthesis method for designing a circular array based wireless sensor network ( mwsn ) . by optimizing array directivity subject to rein and sidelobe constrains , the maximum possible directivity can be achieved .<n> the optimized array of gwsn may have a smaller size with the same directivity compared with conventional array , and the receive mw sn can be miniaturized . the benefits of the method have been demonstrated by the simulation results . <n> wireless sensor networks ( wsns ) are used in various applications , such as point - to - point communication , wireless local area network ( wlan ) and distributed computing . in order to realize a reliable and efficient channel , it is very important to design an array of sensors , which can be used to transmit the information to the receiver . for a wsn to work ,<n> the receiver should be able to detect the transmitted signal with high directivity and low transmit power . to achieve these requirements , many schemes have been proposed . among them , circular array is a very popular design @xcite , because it is easy to realize , in this paper , we propose a two - dimensional ( 2d ) doa estimation method based on the conformal array .<n> the proposed method is an extension of the 2d doa estimator proposed by liu _<n> et al . _ <n> @xcite , which uses a space - time matrix to estimate the 3d density of state ( doa ) of a wireless channel . in this method ,<n> the doa is estimated by a linear programming ( lp ) algorithm , and the estimation error is obtained by the least squares ( lss ) method . by using the lp algorithm to find the optimal lp solution , the estimation accuracy can be further improved . as a result<n> , it has been shown that our method can achieve the same estimation accuracy as that of the state estimation method in some special cases , for example , when the dimension of the channel is very large , or when the number of channels is very small . moreover , this method can be applied to the case when the channel has a non - conformal structure , such as for example in the case of conformal antenna array , where the channel can not be

samples.source_preview:
microparticle adhesion is central to fundamental areas such as surface science @xcite , geological material mechanics @xcite , granular media dynamics @xcite , and even planet formation @xcite . 
 improved understanding of microparticle adhesion has implications for applied areas including self - assembly @xcite , laser cleaning of semiconductors @xcite , powder processing @xcite , and drug delivery @xcite . 
 one method to study microparticle adhesion is to use laser - generated acoustic waves
samples.reference: the detachment of a semi - ordered monolayer of polystyrene microspheres adhered to an aluminum - coated glass substrate is studied using a laser - induced spallation technique . the microsphere - substrate adhesion force is estimated from substrate surface displacement measurements obtained using optical interferometry , and a rigid - body model that accounts for the inertia of the microspheres . the estimated adhesion force is compared with estimates obtained from interferometric measurement of the out - of - plane microsphere contact resonance . reasonable agreement is found between the two experiments . scanning electron microscope images of detached monolayer regions reveal a unique morphology , namely , partially detached monolayer flakes composed of single hexagonal close packed crystalline domains . this work contributes to an improved understanding of microsphere adhesion and demonstrates a unique monolayer delamination morphology .
samples.generated: we study the adhesion of a semi - ordered polystyrene ( ps ) microsphere monolayer to an aluminum - coated glass substrate , using a laser - induced spallation technique . the particle - substrate adhesive force is estimated by monitoring the time - resolved displacements of the surface of the substrate without the monolayer via optical inteferometry , and applying a rigid - body model that accounts for the microsphere inertia . we compare the estimated adhesive force with estimations based on measurements of the out - of - plane contact resonance of the ps microspheres .<n> we find that the force acting on the substrate is proportional to the square root of the particle size , @xmath0 , which is in agreement with the theoretical prediction for a rigid body model , but is significantly smaller than the estimated force based on the contact resonance measurements . in the case of delaminated monolayer areas ,<n> we observe a unique morphology wherein the mono layer has fractured into flakes that have partially reattached to the substrate and are composed of mostly single crystalline domains . spallation is a ubiquitous phenomenon in physics , chemistry , biology , and materials science .<n> it occurs when a macroscopic object , such as an atom , a molecule , or a nanoparticle , is subjected to an applied force that causes it to oscillate in time and space @xcite . in recent years<n> , there has been an explosion of interest in the use of spallations in a variety of fields , including self - assembly , laser cleaning , powder processing , drug delivery , etc . here , we present the first experimental results of laser - induced spasllation in a monolayer of micrometer - sized ps microspheres adhered to an aluminum - coated film . by generating longitudinal acoustic waves at the air - water interface ,<n> we measure the oscillation frequency of the microsphere as a function of time , from which we obtain the adhesion force between the sphere and the film , as well as the contact radius of the sphere . using the measured adhesion force and the dmt contact model , the work of adhesion of the monolayer<n> is estimated to be @xmath0n , which is significantly higher than the value predicted by van der waals

samples.source_preview:
in the risk minimisation of portfolio optimisation it is very important to consider how the returns of different companies correlate with each other . for this purpose 
 the study of the equal time cross correlations between stocks has attracted much interest  @xcite : the clustering properties and the comparison between the time and ensemble averages have provided much useful information in this respect .    in statistical physics _ 
 time dependent _ correlations are also of major interest . d
samples.reference: we study the time dependent cross correlations of stock returns , i.e. we measure the correlation as the function of the time shift between pairs of stock return time series using tick - by - tick data . we find a weak but significant effect showing that in many cases the maximum correlation appears at nonzero time shift indicating directions of influence between the companies . due to the weakness of this effect and the shortness of the characteristic time ( of the order of a few minutes ) our findings are compatible with market efficiency . the interaction of companies defines a directed network of influence .
samples.generated: we study time - dependent cross - correlations between the returns of different stocks taken from the new york stock exchange .<n> it is shown that there exists some  pulling '' effect between the companies , _<n> i.e. _ , one of them influences the price behaviour of the others . however , this effect can not be strong and the shift should be small , otherwise the effect could be utilized for arbitrage purposes , which is excluded from an efficient market . we have analyzed the time dependent cross correlation functions of the returns of stocks at the nyse .<n> we have found two types of mechanisms to generate significant correlation between two stocks : a ) some external effect ( e.g. economic , political news etc . ) that influences both stock prices simultaneously ; b ) one of the stocks has an influence on the other (  pulling '' the other ) . in this case<n> the more frequently traded companies are influencing the less frequently traded ones . as for the pulling effect we found that generically the more traded , and thus more important companies pull the other one . we have studied whether there exists any pulling effect between stocks , i.e. , whether at a given time the return value of one stock influences that of another stock at a different time . here , we analyzed the correlation of 195 companies , which were traded during the available 54 days more than 15000 times . for the resulting 195 * 194/2 correlation functions we measured the maximum value , the position at which the maximum was found , as well as the ratio , of the maximum and strength of the noise , defined as the variance of the correlation values for time shift in this paper , we study the effect of finite size on the price dynamics of s&p500 stocks .<n> we show that the price of a stock decreases as the size of its portfolio increases , and we derive the power - law decay of the price as a function of the mean portfolio size . <n> stock markets are characterized by large fluctuations and extreme events . as a consequence ,<n> the price volatility is one of the main factors influencing stock market returns . in the last decade<n> , there has been an increasing interest in the study of stock markets as a means of understanding the dynamics of economic systems . from a mathematical point of view , the problem is complicated by the fact that the standard , i.e. , markovian , brownian motion of the hamiltonian , which describes the evolution of the stock price , is , in general , not self - consistent . on the other hand , from a technical point of views , it is possible to study the _ canonical _ , or self - similar , motion of a random walk @xmath0 on the stock market , where the mean and the variance of the prices are given by @

samples.reference: gas outflows appear to be a phenomenon shared by the vast majority of quasars . observations indicate that there is wide range in outflow prominence . in this paper we review how the 4d eigenvector 1 scheme helps to organize observed properties and lead to meaningful constraints on the outflow physical and dynamical processes .
samples.generated: we review recent progress in understanding the physical processes at work in quasar outflows .<n> we concentrate on physical processes related to the dynamics of the broad emission line region ( blr ) , and in particular on the role of outflows in the ionization of the host galaxy and the intergalactic medium . <n> [ 1999/12/01 v1.4c il nuovo cimento ] i review the observational status of resonant line acceleration ( ) in quasars .<n> the presence of resonant acceleration has been known since the mid-1980s , when it was first suggested for and lines . since then<n> , it has become clear that the lines are accelerated in outflows that continue to see unabsorbed continuum photons because of their changing velocity with distance from the central continuum source . in this case<n> the outflow is accelerated by the line photons that are emitted by gas that continues to see the continuum photons as it moves toward us . <n> it is now well established that the blueshift of the line with respect to the rest frame of the continuum source is a general feature of all broad emission lines , in particular of the high - ionization lines ( hils ) , and that this effect is most prominent in the very - broad line region ( vblr ) and in the innermost region ( i.e. , @xmath0 pc ) of the broad line profile . however , until recently it was not clear whether or not this effect was present in other types of lines : in particular , there was no clear evidence for it in the low - ionization emission lines ( we discuss the physical conditions of the line emitting gas in the blr of type 1 quasars .<n> the lowest blueshifted emission lines ( i.e. , and ) are emitted by gas with a very low eddington ratio , @xmath0@xmath1 , indicating that the gas is in a gravitationally bound region . radiative acceleration is required if this gas is to be unbound . in the presence of a radiation force ,<n> the lower density gas is heated to high temperatures , e.g. by a strong uv radiation field . as a result<n> , the lowest density gas can be heated to x - ray temperatures of a few kev , where it remains for a while after which the radiation pressure of the gas dominates . the lowest emission lines are emitted in outflows , which are driven by radiation forces , as indicated by the dependence of the blueshifts of the balmer lines on the eddington ratios of the outflows @xcite . here<n> we present the results of a search for low - ionization emission lines in the archival spectra of the sloan digital sky survey ( sdss ) . using the i review the observational evidence for the presence of outflows in quasars and discuss how new observational capabilities , in particular the multiplexing capability of xshooter , will contribute to a better understanding of these phenomena . <n> address = instituto de astronoma , universidad nacional autnoma de mxico , + apartado postal 70 - samples.source_preview:
the laser interferometer gravitational wave observatory ( ligo )  @xcite is approaching its target sensitivity , and numerous scientific studies by the ligo scientific collaboration ( lsc ) are in progress . 
 the analysis of the data from the first scientific run , s1 , is now complete , and the results of searches for continuous waves from pulsars  @xcite , the `` inspiral '' ( orbital decay ) of compact binary systems  @xcite , short bursts  @xcite , and an isotropic stochastic background  @x
samples.reference: ligo recently conducted its third scientific data run , s3 . here we summarize the veto and data quality studies conducted by the ligo scientific collaboration in connection with the search for binary inspiral signals in the s3 data . ligo s interferometer channels and physical environmental monitors were monitored , and events in these channels coincident with inspiral triggers were examined .
samples.generated: we present the results of a study of data quality and vetoes in the search for inspiral signals in the data from the ligo 4 and 2 interferometers .<n> we also describe specific vetoes that will be used in the final search for gravitational wave signals from compact binary objects in the s3 data . the laser interferometer gravitational - wave observatory ( lsc ) consists of an array of four identical , high - repetition - rate ( @xmath0 hz ) , linearly - polarized laser diodes arranged in a ring array .<n> the primary mission of the lsc is to search for gravitational waves in the frequency range of 100 hz to 10 hz using a large number of inspiral templates . <n> the inspiral analysis of the s3 ligo data revealed a number of effective data quality flags . in an attempt to find a way to safely reject inspiral triggers<n> , we were able to identify candidate inspiral vetoes , and we were also able to find two good candidate veto channels for the h2 inspiral data . through the use of these veto channels ,<n> inspiral events were successfully rejected for many of the h1 and h2 playground data samples . as a result<n> we are able to rule out gravitational wave events from the ligo inspiral sample with a confidence greater than 95% , which is the highest of any gravitational wave search experiment to date . with the discovery of the second harmonic of the cosmic microwave background ( cmb ) @xcite , the ligo detectors are sensitive to gravitational waves up to a strength of @xmath0 @xcite .<n> gravitational wave bursts ( gws ) , which are bursts of gravitational radiation emitted at the end of a short period of time , are among the most exciting examples of gravitational wave sources . <n> the laser interferometer gravitational - wave observatory ( ligo ) is a ground - based gravitational wave observatory consisting of three identical detectors , each with its own array of sensitive , high - resolution , single - dish detectors : a ) the s3 detector located at the north celestial pole , b ) a s2 detector at the fred lawrence whipple observatory ( flwo ) in berkeley , ca , and c ) an array of four identical detectors located in the south celestial pole ( scp ) of the nasa goddard space flight center ( _ gsfc _ ) that are designed to search for gw bursts . in 2002 ,<n> the first phase of the detectors was completed and in 2004 , the second phase began . during the first two years of operation , ligo detected more than 100

samples.source_preview:
the process of backscattering and fluorescence of x - rays from cosmic matter known as x - ray reflection is commonly observed throughout astronomy . 
 we are concerned here with the situation where the x - ray irradiation is so intense that it determines the ionization state of the material . 
 this occurs in accreting x - ray sources such as galactic black hole candidates ( bhc ) and active galactic nuclei ( agn ) , and may also be relevant to gamma - ray bursts ( grb ) . 
 the irradiated gas
samples.reference: x - ray ionized reflection occurs when a surface is irradiated with x - rays so intense that its ionization state is determined by the ionization parameter @xmath0 , where @xmath1 is the incident flux and @xmath2 the gas density . it occurs in accretion , onto compact objects including black holes in both active galaxies and stellar - mass binaries , and possibly in gamma - ray bursts . computation of model reflection spectra is often time - consuming . here we present the results from a comprehensive grid of models computed with our code , which has now been extended to include what we consider to be all energetically - important ionization states and transitions . this grid is being made available as an ionized - reflection model , reflion , for xspec . quality spectra have been obtained for hundreds of agn with the _ we present a new method to determine the ionization structure of a photoionized plasma .<n> the method is based on the assumption that the plasma is isothermal and that the electron density is constant throughout the process . by comparing the results of this method with the monte - carlo simulation of the plasma<n> , we show that the ionization fraction can be determined accurately for a wide range of temperatures and densities . <n> epsf epsf <n> [ firstpage ] atomic processes in the interstellar medium ( ism ) have been the subject of intensive studies since the early days of the _ hubble space telescope _ ( _ hst _ ) , because of the importance of the ism as a local laboratory for testing theoretical models of the early universe and for investigating the nature of the large - at high energies in the framework of the perturbative quantum chromodynamics strong interactions are mediated by the exchenge of hard pomerons , which are non - local entities propagating according to the bfkl equation and splitting into two or merging from two to one with the known triple pomeron vertex . 
 neglecting pomeron loops and choosing the projectile to have a short range and the target to be a heavy nucleus one comes to the well - known balitski - kovchegov ( bk ) equation , which sum
samples.reference: hadron - nucleus amplitudes at high energies are studied in the `` toy '' regge model in zero transverse dimension for finite nuclei , when the standard series of fan diagrams is converted into a finite sum and looses physical sense at quite low energies . taking into account all the loop contributions by numerical methods we find a physically meaningful amplitudes at all energies . they practically coincide with the amplitudes for infinite nuclei . a surprizing result is that for finite nuclei and small enough triple pomeron coupling the infinite series of fan diagrams describes the amplitude quite well in spite of the fact that in reality the series should be cut and as such deprived of any physical sense at high energies .
samples.generated: we study the structure of the balitski - kovchegov ( bk ) amplitude in the toy model of a pomeron field with a non - hermitian interaction .<n> we establish the relation between the sum of fan diagrams and the full amplitude . the rapidity @xmath0 dependence of the cross section for elastic nucleus - nucleus scattering is calculated in the glauber approach .<n> it is shown that the amplitude depends on three variables : the scaled rapidity , the ratio of the initial and final rapidities , and the atomic number of the target nucleus . in the limit of very high rapidities<n> the amplitude is given in terms of only two variables , one of which is proportional to the scattering cross section in the optical approximation . <n> elastic scattering of nuclei is one of the most important reactions in nuclear physics because of its important role in the understanding of the structure of nuclei and in the formation of the first excited states of heavy nuclei @xcite . for the description of heavy - ion collisions at intermediate and high energies one<n> usually resort to the so - called optical approximation which assumes that the initial state of the projectile and the target are in the same physical state , that is , they have the same quantum numbers . however , this approximation fails at high energies and/or for nuclei with large values of the bjorken parameter , which is the case for example for light nuclei like light elements , where the effective coupling to the nucleus is the amplitude for the inclusive process @xmath0 with triple pomeron coupling is calculated for nuclei with different numbers of valence nucleons .<n> it is shown that the finite sum of fan diagrams correctly describes the amplitude up to a certain value of rapidity , after which the result sharply blows up practically to infinity . for finite nuclei the amplitude with loop contributions<n> is found to be practically identical with the one which corresponds to the infinite nucleus . at large rapidities<n> the found amplitude is weakly dependent on the initial amplitude at zero energies , so that it is formed completely from loop contributions . <n> [ [ section ] ] since the discovery of the higgs boson @xcite , the so - called higgs mechanism has attracted a great deal of interest in particle physics and nuclear physics . among many possible mechanisms the mechanism proposed by hamitonian and glashow<n> is the most attractive , because it can explain the origin of the quark - gluon plasma ( qgp ) , one of the most interesting phenomena in nuclear physics today . in this mechanism<n> the pomeron exchange between quarks and gluons is responsible for the formation of the qgp from the decays of hadrons . the in this paper , we present a new method for the detection of gravitational waves ( gws ) .<n> this method is based on the use of the time - resolved intensity modulation ( trm ) technique , which allows us to obtain the intensity profile of the gw signal . in this way<n> we are able to detect gravitational waves with an angular resolution that is ten times better than with the conventional trm technique . <n> gw detection is one of the most studied techniques in the field of gravitational wave astronomy . due to the high sensitivity of gw detectors to small changes in the local environment<n> , it has been shown to be useful in many fields , such as cosmology , gravitational wave detection , astrophysics , earth and planetary sciences @xcite . however , the detection efficiency in these fields is still very low , @xmath0 , even in the most advanced detectors such as the lisa gravitational wave detector , einstein telescope or space telescope . as a result ,<n> detection is still a very challenging task , especially in the case of gravitational - wave detection in the earth s gravitational field , where the sensitivity is still so low that no detection is possible
